sanskrit_verse: इदं शास्त्रमधीयानो ब्राह्मणः शंसितव्रतः । मनोवाक्देहजैर्नित्यं कर्मदोषैर्न लिप्यते ॥ १.१०४॥
transliteration: idaṃ śāstramadhīyāno brāhmaṇaḥ śaṃsitavratḥ | manovākdehajairnityaṃ karmadoṣairna lipyate || 1.104||
sph_interpretive_translation: The Brāhmaṇa who studies this scripture with declared vows remains untouched by faults arising perpetually from mind, speech, and body.
jurisprudential_principles: Capacity-based responsibility rooted in spiritual discipline
executable_legal_axioms: IF agent engages in declared-scriptural-study THEN immunity-to-karmic-liability IS granted
IF mental-speech-body-actions ARE aligned WITH vow THEN liability-determination IS nullified
IF consciousness-state IS stabilized THROUGH śāstra THEN consequence-allocation IS suspended
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, the threshold of liability shifts from act-based guilt to consciousness-state verification. Authority lies in the alignment of action with declared spiritual discipline rather than external compliance. Restoration occurs when the actor returns to scriptural engagement.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that causality arises from volition aligned with dharma. Anupūrvaśaḥ shows that repeated scriptural engagement dissolves karmic misalignment. Responsibility is proportional to awareness-depth. The non-punitive reality rule confirms that purity displaces impurity without requiring corrective suffering.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Capacity restoration through purified consciousness protocols
final_declaration: By the Source-Authority of the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, this Dharma is executed. The Brāhmaṇa's immunity through śāstric discipline affirms Dharma as restored, reality as non-punitive, and consciousness as the supreme adjudicator.
